### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

Given a module "MyModule"
Do
```
Import-Module -Name mymodule
Update-Help -Module MyModule
```



### Expected behavior

```console
Help should update without error.

1: It should use the module name as specified in the module definition and not depend on the name it was imported with.

2: It should not report an error since it automatically recovered from the failed getting of the help file with the wrong name.

If you spell MyModule correctly on import, then no error on Update-Help.

If you do not import the module first, then no error on Update-Help.
```


### Actual behavior

```console
Update-Help attempts to contact the server named in `HelpInfoURI` of the PSD1 file, something like:

`$($HelpInfoURI)/mymodule_$($guid)_HelpInfo.xml`

Then it will try again, with the correct spelling
`$($HelpInfoURI)/MyModule_$($guid)_HelpInfo.xml`

Even though it actually did update the help file, it still reports an error.
```

comments.author: theJasonHelmick
comments.body:
Hi @jporkka - thanks for reporting this. The reason this occurs is because the web service hosting the help content is case sensitive. While PowerShell and the cmdlets are case insensitive, outside services (such as the hosting system for help) may have different criteria. The module name that you type is built as part of the url that the web service uses to locate the help content. If the module name is not typed in the proper case, then failures may occur. This is documented here for additional reference in the last two paragraphs. * https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/microsoft.powershell.core/about/about_case-sensitivity?view=powershell-7.3 *
about Case-Sensitivity - PowerShell
This article explains how PowerShell handles case-sensitivity.

comments.author: jporkka
comments.body:
I understand that, but what I was reporting are 2 problems:

#1: PowerShell has the module definition and knows the correct case to use. it should not depend on what the user typed when importing the module.

#2 It didn't actually fail -- it reported an error as if it failed, but in fact it was successful. 
The error is from an intermediate step and should not get reported to the user.

comments.author: theJasonHelmick
comments.body: @jporkka - To your point, after discussing with the WG, this doesn't seem to be good behavior. We are continuing our conversation about possible fixes and I will report back here.

title: Update-Help reports an error when the module is imported with the wrong case.
